“我是一名企业家。我是创始人。这就是我的思想和大脑的运作方式。”Whitney Wolfe Herd 在 11 月 6 日接受《财富》杂志采访时沉思道，当天她宣布将辞去 Bumble（她于 2014 年创立的约会应用程序）首席执行官一职。 Wolfe Herd 女士此前，她曾共同创立了竞争对手应用程序 Tinder，她承认自己对运营一家上市公司的苦差事缺乏热情。她将担任执行主席，花时间“展望爱与联系的未来”。

Lidiane Jones 将接替她的位置，她目前负责运营 Slack，这是一个聊天平台，于 2021 年被科技巨头 Salesforce 收购。Slack 的创始人斯图尔特·巴特菲尔德 (Stewart Butterfield) 在今年年初辞去了老板职务。投资者希望琼斯女士能少花点时间着眼于未来，多花些时间在当下。自 2021 年公司上市以来，Bumble 的股价已下跌 82%。沃尔夫·赫德 (Wolfe Herd) 女士将 Bumble 打造成更广泛的女性交友和职业联系平台的宏伟愿景却失败了。与此同时，它还陷入了与主要竞争对手 Match Group 的增长争夺战中，后者拥有 Tinder 和包括 Hinge 在内的各种其他约会应用程序。成本上升了。

投资者长期以来一直在创始人领导的公司中发现了优点。事实上，在 Wolfe Herd 女士宣布重组的当天，Bumble 的股价下跌了 4%。风险投资 ( VC ) 巨头本·霍洛维茨 (Ben Horowitz) 认为，创始人兼老板比进口技术更能发现技术的转变。由于公司是他们一生的工作，因此他们通常能够以更长远的眼光看待并押注于可能需要数年时间才能获得回报的创新想法。

然而，有迹象表明，在资本不再便宜、投资者更喜欢今天拥挤而不是明天拥挤的世界里，所谓的“创始人溢价”可能正在减弱。 《经济学人》分析了风险投资机构 Bessemer Venture Partners 编制的纳斯达克新兴云指数中公开上市软件公司的表现。从 2018 年到 2021 年底，该指数中创始人领导的公司的股价比其他公司高出一半（见图 1）。然而，从 2022 年开始，这种差距消失了。

要了解原因，请考虑指数中的创始人兼老板在研发方面投入更多资金、更快地扩大团队、实现更高的收入增长，但产生的现金较少（见图 2）。在过去十年的科技繁荣时期，创始人的成功主要取决于他们设定大胆愿景、从风险投资家那里筹集资金、吞噬人才以及在可能的竞争对手中抢占先机的能力。投资者现在要求更加关注成本和更快地获取利润。

创始人要做什么？一种选择是磨炼他们的远大抱负，将自己重塑为挑剔的资本管理者。在引起投资者的愤怒后，科技巨头 Meta 的创始人马克·扎克伯格(Mark Zuckerberg)淡化了建立元宇宙的宏伟计划，并在 2 月份宣布 2023 年将是听起来令人高兴的“效率年”。其股价已恢复了去年损失的大部分价值。

11月2日，电商平台Shopify公布了7月至9月的季度业绩。投资者因恢复盈利而欢呼雀跃；其股价当日上涨22%。 5 月份，该公司裁员 20%，并剥离了物流部门。其联合创始人兼老板托比亚斯·吕特克(Tobias Lütke)承认，该公司因“支线任务”而分心，并且在疫情期间增长过快。由联合创始人马克·贝尼奥夫 (Marc Benioff) 运营的 Salesforce 又提供了一个例子。多年来，该公司将增长置于利润之上，并大手笔进行收购，其中包括斥资 280 亿美元收购 Slack。随着去年科技行业的下滑，激进投资者包围了该公司。作为回应，该公司裁员 10%，暂停收购并提高价格。它的努力也得到了投资者的回报。

然而，正如沃尔夫·赫德女士的言论所暗示的那样，所有这些对于一些创始人来说可能听起来非常乏味。有些人可能会彻底退出——巴特菲尔德先生现在把时间花在园艺和购买豪华房产上。其他人，比如沃尔夫·赫德女士，会选择塑造一个更符合自己喜好的角色，把创造利润的繁琐工作留给其他人。这种安排是否有效可能取决于所涉及的人物。北卡罗来纳大学的布拉德利·亨德里克斯指出，尽管创始人比经验丰富的专业人士更需要建议，但他们也更有可能忽视建议。如果创始人的宏伟希望和他们引进的老板的务实优先事项之间出现紧张关系，可能会擦出火花。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 14:01:38 GMT /内容/0f6163dj7thcrda14fcdonus55u9gefr https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/09/when-should-a-Founder-step-down The Bob Iger v Nelson Peltz rematch

当这封写给迪士尼高层的信收到时，是毁灭性的。它提到了电视业务的失败、士气低落、管理不善、主题公园投资不足以及“你们一贯拒绝制定明确的继任计划”。它要求首席执行官辞职。这听起来像是维权投资者纳尔逊·佩尔茨 (Nelson Peltz) 向迪士尼首席执行​​官鲍勃·艾格 (Bob Iger) 发送的那种信件，他已获得了对这家娱乐巨头价值约 25 亿美元的股份的控制权。但事实并非如此。艾格先生的自传中引用了这封信，是沃尔特·迪士尼的侄子罗伊·迪士尼在大约 20 年前写给艾格先生的前任迈克尔·艾斯纳的信，这封信导致了艾斯纳先生的垮台，并将艾格先生推上了魔法王国的宝座。在所有人中，他应该知道这样的信息有多么致命。

称其为迪士尼的“圣诞节前的噩梦”。 81 岁的特里安基金管理公司 (Trian Fund Management) 联合创始人佩尔茨 (Peltz) 结束了迪士尼董事会席位的代理权争夺战，让艾格 (Iger) 得到了急需的喘息机会。九个月后，这位出生于布鲁克林的亿万富翁又回到了战争轨道上。如果说有什么不同的话，那就是他的武装比以前更好了。将自己的股份加入到特里安的股份中的是艾萨克·“艾克”·珀尔穆特 (Isaac “Ike” Perlmutter)，他是一位 80 岁的前以色列士兵，2009 年以 40 亿美元的价格将自己的公司漫威娱乐 (Marvel Entertainment) 卖给了艾格先生，使他成为迪士尼最大的投资者之一，也是迪士尼的常客。 CEO这边。 （反过来，艾格先生将珀尔穆特先生描绘成一个偏执的吝啬鬼，对娱乐的创意方面不感兴趣。）

佩尔茨先生和珀尔穆特先生住在佛罗里达州棕榈滩，住得很近，据了解，他们持有的迪士尼股票不到 2%，他们认为迪士尼股票的表现连续低于股市，而不仅仅是艾格先生第二次担任首席执行官以来。大约一年前，但自他第一个 15 年任期（于 2020 年结束）中期开始。他们希望进行以股东为中心的改组，并在董事会中拥有多个席位。 72 岁的艾格先生正在争分夺秒地为迪士尼寻找正确的战略方向，并为自己寻找潜在的继任者。 11月8日，该公司报告7月至9月季度利润好于预期，并宣布将提高成本削减目标。艾格先生宣称，公司已准备好“超越这段修复期，重新开始建设我们的业务”。佩尔茨先生是否同意还有待观察。

艾格先生已经在加强他的反特里安防御。 11 月 6 日，迪士尼宣布任命休·约翰斯顿 (Hugh Johnston) 为首席财务官，将他从担任百事可乐首席财务官13 年的他挖走。在那段时间里，约翰斯顿帮助挫败了佩尔茨两年来拆分这家饮料和零食巨头的企图，让他亲身体验了这位激进分子的策略。艾格先生还可能认为这位新员工是 2026 年合同到期时接替他的潜在候选人，这可能会解决困扰他的遗产的一个棘手问题。

不过，这场战斗不仅仅关乎未来。如果佩尔茨先生发表了一份著名的“白皮书”来阐明他对迪士尼的担忧，那么它很可能会集中在艾格先生最近的领导失误上，以及一家公司的治理上，该公司的董事会从董事长到下层似乎都在受他的奴役。 “以首席执行官为中心的董事会是成功代理权争夺的完美目标，”特拉华州纽瓦克温伯格公司治理中心创始人查尔斯·埃尔森 (Charles Elson) 表示。 “这是一个明智之举。”

艾格在首次担任首席执行官期间就开始为自己挖坑，其中一部分时间他还担任了董事长。他多次推迟退休，然后与继任者鲍勃·查佩克(Bob Chapek)多次发生冲突，直到两年后重新担任首席执行官一职。现任董事长马克·帕克 (Mark Parker) 于 4 月上任，他于 2016 年在艾格先生的领导下首次加入董事会，这使得他以及 2020 年之前任命的其他六名在任董事会成员对艾格先生的继任计划惨败负有部分责任。此外，帕克先生是运动鞋零售商耐克的执行董事长，这意味着他同时管理着两家标准普尔500 指数公司的董事会。除非他本人就是漫威角色，否则这对一个人来说似乎是难以承担的责任。

2019 年，艾格牵头以 710 亿美元收购了电影公司 21 世纪福克斯公司，当时许多现任董事会成员都在迪士尼工作，这让迪士尼背上了债务。当该公司推出亏损的流媒体服务 Disney+ 时，他们还对内容进行了大量支出。今年，董事会似乎也没有采取任何措施来帮助澄清艾格先生的想法。他有三个战略难题需要解决。首先是决定迪士尼电视业务的未来，包括体育频道ESPN ，这些业务曾经是该公司的摇钱树，但现在正遭受有线电视捆绑业务缓慢消亡的影响。就连拥有印度次大陆板球转播权的前宝石印度之星公司的未来也正在接受审查。第二个目标是遏制 Disney+ 的亏损，并与有线电视公司康卡斯特 (Comcast) 就迪士尼与其竞争对手共同拥有的另一家流媒体服务 Hulu 的其余部分达成合理价格。第三是对公园业务进行再投资，其中包括迪士尼乐园，佩尔茨先生指责迪士尼榨取迪士尼乐园来支持其媒体业务。今年到目前为止，艾格在电视资产出售问题上忽冷忽热，并在改变主意之前表示不愿购买Hulu。至于公园，他最近宣布了 600 亿美元的投资，但这已经超过十年了，其中大部分可能会在他预期任期结束后支出。

耳朵！耳朵！

佩尔茨先生可能无法解决迪士尼的问题。他并不总是赢得战斗，但也会失败。除了百事可乐（特里安至少从股价上涨中受益）之外，他对通用电气这家企业集团的投资却是一次巨大的失败。他不像罗伊那样流淌着迪士尼的血液，也不一定知道如何修复这家公司。但让董事会对股东比对艾格先生负责是正确的起点。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 13:59:47 GMT /内容/slib93pnqc0gmm2gf09hsphvqh9ubip3 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/09/the-bob-iger-v-nelson-peltz-rematch India is in the midst of an unusual IPO boom

希望从印度经济增长中获利的投资者通常要么将注意力集中在该国大亨经营的庞大企业集团上，要么将注意力集中在改变印度人购物、学习或出行方式的热闹科技公司上。那么，如何解释 Cello World 这家拥有 61 年历史的中等规模公司于 11 月 6 日在当地两家交易所上市的兴奋之情呢？它生产印度人用来携带午餐去学校或工作的“午餐盒”，以及廉价的钢笔和模制家具——这些东西都没什么令人兴奋的。然而，其股价在交易首日就飙升了 29%，市值超过 20 亿美元。这几乎是上一财年净利润的 60 倍。其首次公开募股 ( IPO ) 获得约 40 倍的超额认购。

Cello World 没有大胆的计划将此次发行筹集的 2.3 亿美元进行再投资；所有这些都将回到控制该公司的家族手中，该家族仍拥有 81% 的股权。该业务也不是独一无二的。上月底，另一家钢笔制造公司 Flairwriting Industries 获得了首次公开募股的批准。几家家具公司也准备在不久的将来发行股票。简而言之，大提琴世界相当无聊。

很少有风险投资家愿意排队购买这样一家企业的股份。外国投资组合经理中的许多人已经确定了通过在印度最强大的企业集团中持有少量股份进入印度的战略，但他们也可能会放弃这一计划。然而，最近几个月的情况表明，印度经济中最有吸引力的部分之一可能是像 Cello World 这样的公司，它们正在从该国的增长故事中受益，而不是试图书写它。

从去年年底开始，由于投资者对连锁酒店OYO和在线学习公司 Byju's 等亏损的初创公司失去了耐心，印度私募市场的估值暴跌。公共市场也下跌。物流初创公司 Delhivery 于 2022 年初大张旗鼓地上市，其股价暴跌。今年1月，卖空者兴登堡针对印度大亨高塔姆·阿达尼商业帝国会计实务的一份报告，动摇了外国投资者的信心，并引起人们对印度多家企业集团盈利能力疲弱的关注。 。 （阿达尼集团否认有任何不当行为。）

情绪转变的第一个迹象是 4 月份，避孕套和妊娠测试产品制造商 Mankind Pharma 上市。该公司以其稳定的收入增长（从 2020 年的约 7.5 亿美元增至 2022 年的 10 亿美元）和健康的利润吸引了投资者。人们很快就发现，在经历超常增长的经济体的普通领域，有吸引力的机会比比皆是。

随后出现了大量的清单。截至 11 月初，今年已有 194 家公司上市，高于 2022 年全年的 144 家公司（见图表）。投资银行杰富瑞 (Jefferies) 计算出，近期印度IPO中 72% 的超额认购至少是十倍。除了 Cello World 和 Mankind Pharma 等消费品公司外，投资者还抢购了建筑、钢铁和电气元件等其他通常不起眼的行业新上市公司的股票。尽管不处于技术前沿，但其中许多公司都受益于印度政府支持国内制造业（以中国为代价）和改善国家基础设施的努力。 9 月份上市的电缆制造商 RR Kabel 就是这样的公司之一。 11月6日，该公司报告称，7月至9月的季度利润同比翻了一番。

上市热潮没有放缓的迹象。另外 29 项公开发行申请已获得印度证券监管机构的批准，另有 46 项申请目前正在考虑中。正在发行股票的公司包括一家大锤生产商和一家汽车零部件制造商。所有人都希望在明年五月印度大选之前上市。 IIFL证券公司（一家为今年许多上市公司提供融资的投资银行）的 Nipun Goel 指出，未来 12 至 24 个月的IPO计划看起来很强劲；他打赌这种繁荣可能会持续五到七年。事实上，在十月份，考虑到这一切，他的公司搬到了空间三倍的新办公室。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 09:09:47 GMT /内容/a43avvni1f4je9n0gh30l6ri50ddi3lv https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/09/india-is-in-the-mid-of-an-unusual-ipo-boom The fall of WeWork shows the deepening cracks in property

自2010年成立以来，WeWork从未实现过盈利。多年来，由于其浮夸的创始人亚当·诺依曼(Adam Neumann)扭曲现实的权力，它的现金火炬方式从未受到挑战，他成功地让投资者，尤其是软银，相信它不是一家办公室租赁公司，而是一家充满活力的科技公司。 “提升世界意识”的使命。其豪华的办公空间、免费啤酒和桌上足球在世界各地如雨后春笋般涌现。 2019 年初，在首次公开募股 ( IPO ) 前夕，该公司的估值达到了 470 亿美元。

事情很快就开始瓦解，外部投资者对其泡沫般的估值犹豫不决，并对诺伊曼对公司实行铁腕控制的非正统治理安排提出质疑。首次公开募股被搁置，诺伊曼先生被提供 17 亿美元的离职条件。桑迪普·马特拉尼 (Sandeep Mathrani) 是一名房地产资深人士，被任命来管理该公司，他尽最大努力通过削减成本和重新谈判租赁来扭转局面。 2021年，他通过一家特殊目的收购公司将该公司在纽约证券交易所上市，估值为90亿美元。然而，由于疫情导致办公市场低迷以及向远程工作的持久转变，他的努力化为泡影。 11 月 6 日，WeWork 申请破产，该公司在 39 个国家/地区的 777 个地点租赁办公室。它的股权可能会被消灭。

WeWork 并不是唯一一家陷入困境的房地产企业。几天前，在大西洋的另一边，曾经著名的奥地利房地产巨头雷内·本科(René Benko)被逐出西尼亚(Signa)，这个他在过去二十年里建立的价值230亿欧元（合250亿美元）的房地产帝国。其投资组合包括纽约克莱斯勒大厦等标志性建筑； K a D e W e，柏林的一家豪华百货公司；以及伦敦另一家豪华消费殿堂塞尔福里奇百货公司的股份。它还包括豪华酒店，例如维也纳的柏悦酒店；高端开发项目，包括汉堡的 65 层摩天大楼 Elbtower；以及其他零售公司的抓包。许多欧洲商界名人都持有本科先生房地产集团的股份，其中包括巧克力制造商 Lindt & Sprüngli 董事长恩斯特·坦纳 (Ernst Tanner)、建筑企业家汉斯·彼得·哈塞尔斯坦纳 (Hans Peter Haselsteiner) 和咖啡巨头阿瑟·尤格斯特 (Arthur Eugster)。

这两个案例并不完全相同。与 WeWork 不同的是，Signa 并未宣布破产，尽管它面临着流动性紧缩，并聘请了著名的德国破产专家阿恩特·盖维茨 (Arndt Geiwitz) 来接管。与诺伊曼先生不同，本科先生是一位白手起家的高中辍学生，他的职业生涯始于将家乡因斯布鲁克的阁楼改造成顶层公寓，直到他被驱逐为止，他一直参与西尼亚的工作。 2012年因行贿罪被定罪后，他退出了日常运营职责，但后来接任公司顾问委员会主席。他对盖维茨先生的任命表示祝贺，盖维茨先生帮助德国国家航空公司汉莎航空渡过破产困境，并于 11 月 8 日正式将顾问委员会主席职务移交给他。 Benko 家族基金会仍将是该集团的主要股东。与此同时，诺伊曼只能在一旁对 WeWork 的倒闭进行冷嘲热讽，抱怨该公司“未能充分利用当今比以往任何时候都更重要的产品”。

然而，这两个帝国的兴衰却有相似之处。其一，两者都依赖于高风险的赌注，但在利率上升和房地产市场低迷的世界中，这些赌注都失败了。在建立自己的帝国的过程中，本科先生积累了大量债务，以便在维持丰厚股息的同时购买新资产。这种模式只有在利率较低且优质房产价值持续上涨的情况下才有效。在WeWork的案例中，风险源于一种模式，即对房产进行长期租约，有时长达20年，斥巨资进行时髦的翻新，然后租用空间一次短至一个月。当写字楼市场转向时，该公司被迫支付远远超出其向租户收取的租金的租金，因为有更便宜的替代方案可供选择。

尽管如此，两个帝国都可能变得更加强大。因斯布鲁克大学的莱昂哈德·多布施 (Leonhard Dobusch) 认为，盖维茨将拆分西格纳庞大的投资组合，出售资产以获取现金并偿还债务。由数百家控股公司组成的私营企业需要简化。 WeWork 已获得大多数债权人的支持，将其 30 亿美元的债务转换为股权，使其资产负债表近乎全新。它还将利用破产的机会终止在美国的 60 多项租约，并重新谈判其他租约。 WeWork 新任老板戴维·托利 (David Tolley) 表示，他认为该公司将在不到七个月的时间内处于破产状态。诺伊曼先生和本科先生离开了，但他们所创造的东西可能会持续下去。 ■

; Tue, 07 Nov 2023 21:41:24 GMT /内容/5g4lhmpmdtni0kh2lvknfluk39j61dlo https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/07/the-fall-of-wework-shows-the-deepening-cracks-in-property How to manage teams in a world designed for individuals

团队中没有“我”。但“自动驾驶”中有一个。尽管团队合作在组织中的重要性日益增加，但用于管理员工的流程却与以前一样。老板们可能对合作赞不绝口，但他们奖励、审查和招聘的方式却没有跟上。

组织中的人们总是与其他人协同工作。但出于多种原因，对团队的重视正在日益增长。技术使想法和信息的共享变得更加容易，而混合工作则使其变得更加重要。 （它不被称为 Microsoft Silos 是有原因的。）软件行业已经将团队的福音——敏捷、scrums、 OKR以及所有其他内容——传播到了各个地方。

在我们新的七部分播客系列 《老板课堂》中，我们的巴图比专栏作家寻找成为更好经理的秘诀。第三集探讨如何正确招聘，第四集探讨如何打造一支优秀的团队。

麻省理工学院斯隆管理学院的阿卜杜拉·阿尔马图克最近发表的一篇论文表明，事实证明，团队更擅长解决复杂的问题。研究还表明，人们对工作团队的依恋程度高于对组织的依恋程度。你不太可能带着标志去吃午餐。

关于团队运作的因素的知识也在不断积累，这是本周我们新的管理播客《老板课堂》一集的主题。亚里士多德项目是谷歌对其表现最佳团队的特征进行的一项著名研究，该项目将“心理安全”（说出自己的想法的舒适度）确定为最重要的因素，此外还有可靠性、角色明确性和有意义的工作等。不同的团队擅长不同的事情。芝加哥大学的吴令飞及其合著者的分析发现，团队规模和科学研究类型之间存在相关性：较大的团队开发现有的想法，而较小的团队则用新的想法颠覆该领域。

但对团队的更多重视和理解通常不会转化为匹配的管理实践。招聘流程关注的是个人的成就，而不是他们所在的集体。绩效管理在很大程度上仍然是一项单人运动。评价通常基于个人目标，奖金也是如此。衡量标准通常仅限于具体的产出，而不是基于团队的软性衡量标准，例如人们的信任程度。许多老板根本不知道他们的团队到底在做什么，这也于事无补。软件公司 Soroco 以及哈佛商学院和宾夕法尼亚大学沃顿商学院的学者要求管理者描述他们认为占用团队大部分时间的流程。平均而言，他们不知道或记不起团队成员 60% 的工作，这使得他们更像是高效能的金鱼，而不是老板。

其中大部分都是有充分理由的。人是一一调职、升迁的，不是以营的形式。根据团队绩效奖励员工可能会导致不公平：搭便车的人可能会得到太多的认可，或者努力工作的人可能会因为其他人没有尽职尽责而受到惩罚。量化团队贡献是很困难的。当团队由来自不同部门的人员组成或组建时间有限时，管理者会发现很难知道他们的直接下属在做什么。

但这些问题并非无法克服。在招聘人员时，可以评估成为优秀团队成员的特质：例如，在一项要求参与者通过眼睛快照确定人们感受的测试中取得良好成绩与成为一名优秀的团队合作者相关。同行评审可以很好地了解人们在团队中的形象。

关于基于团队的奖金可能会鼓励搭便车的担忧似乎也被夸大了。奥胡斯大学的安德斯·弗雷德里克森（Anders Frederiksen）和他的合著者最近进行了一项研究，研究了在制造公司引入基于群体的激励措施的影响，发现它引发了绩效的巨大飞跃。这种跳跃不仅是因为该计划激励现有员工提高效率，还因为它吸引了更具生产力的新员工。

员工是个人；管理者永远不应该忘记这一点。但如果团队是很多奇迹发生的地方，老板们应该有更好的方法来充分利用他们。弄清楚他们整天都在做什么可能是一个很好的起点。 ■

; Mon, 06 Nov 2023 18:06:43 GMT /内容/c86cqlbjvfm045obl9t3550s8va7or23 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/06/how-to-manage-teams-in-a-world-Designed-for-individuals Silicon Valley is piling into the business of snooping

九月初，纽约人可能已经注意到一位不受欢迎的客人在他们的聚会周围徘徊。在劳动节周末前夕，纽约警察局 ( NYPD ) 表示将使用无人机来调查有关庆祝活动的投诉，包括后院聚会。警用无人机在美国进行窥探的现象越来越常见。根据西北普利兹克法学院研究人员最近的一项调查，大约四分之一的警察部队现在使用它们。

更令人惊讶的是这项技术的来源。 Skydio 是纽约市警察局的供应商之一，这是一家硅谷公司，该公司利用人工智能 ( AI ) 使无人机易于飞行，让警员无需接受任何培训即可控制无人机。 Skydio 得到了风险投资 ( VC ) 巨头 Andreessen Horowitz 和同行之一 Accel 的支持。纽约警察局还从另一家初创公司BRINC购买产品，该公司生产配备夜视摄像头的飞行器，可以粉碎窗户。 Chat GPT背后的初创公司 Open AI的 Sam Altman 是BRINC的投资者之一。

硅谷正在帮助美国执法部门窥探麻烦制造者，这似乎有些奇怪。支持国家监控与许多在互联网早期成长起来的美国科技名人所信奉的自由主义价值观格格不入。尽管硅谷在 20 世纪 50 年代就开始为美国国防工业供应芯片，但随着其注意力从导弹转向电子商务和 iPhone，它与国家的关系逐渐萎缩。

现在，随着科技行业寻求新的增长领域，向国家出售产品又重新流行起来。安德森霍洛维茨基金公司的凯瑟琳·博伊尔去年在一篇博客文章中写道，政府是“软件革命中最后的抵抗者”。今年早些时候，该公司推出了“美国活力”基金，投资于政府相关行业。国家正在缓慢但坚定地进入数字时代。 2022 年底，五角大楼向 Alphabet、亚马逊、甲骨文和微软四大科技巨头授予了一份价值 90 亿美元的云计算合同。根据《经济学人》的计算，去年授予企业的联邦合同价值中有 11% 是软件和技术，高于十年前的 8%。

监视是一项正在升级的政府活动。观察和分析的新技术正在改变这个领域。 Axon Enterprise 和 Motorola Solutions 等传统供应商向警方和其他安全组织销售摄像头和各种监控系统，现在也有新贵推出更先进的技术。

其中第一个是无人机。该行业一直由中国制造商大疆创新主导，去年美国销售的无人机近四分之三都由该公司提供。这引起了美国政府圈子的极大担忧。 11月1日，国会提出一项法案，禁止所有联邦政府部门购买中国无人机。包括佛罗里达州在内的一些州已经禁止紧急服务部门这样做。所有这一切对于 Skydio 和Brinc等公司来说都是福音。

其他类型的空中侦察设备也在研发中。另一家初创公司 Skydweller 正在开发一种自动太阳能飞机，这种飞机无需着陆即可充电。该公司表示，这将允许“持续监视”。

第二个方兴未艾的技术是卫星。埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 旗下的火箭公司 SpaceX 及其模仿者帮助将物体送入太空的成本降低到了二十年前水平的十分之一左右。这导致近地轨道上布满了卫星，其中大约八分之一的卫星用于观测地球。另一家风险投资公司 Founders Fund 的 Trae Stephens 表示，数据公司 PitchBook 估计现在有近 200 家公司从事卫星图像销售业务，数量如此之多，以至于市场已经商品化。其中一家公司 BlackSky 表示，它可以每隔一小时左右拍摄一张地球上某个地点的图像。自 2013 年以来，卫星图像已经取得了长足的进步，当时俄勒冈州警方利用 Google 地球的图片发现了居民院子里的非法大麻种植园。

技术人员还销售工具来帮助执法部门更好地利用现在触手可及的大量图像和信息。周围的。 AI是另一家由 Andreessen Horowitz 支持的初创公司，它开发了自动监控摄像头是否存在可疑活动的技术。 Palantir 是一家数据挖掘公司，已融入美国军工联合体，并将其工具出售给洛杉矶警察局等机构。

面部识别软件现在在美国也得到了更广泛的使用，大约十分之一的警察部队可以使用该技术。美国政府问责局9月份发布的一份报告发现，包括联邦调查局和特勤局在内的六个联邦执法机构平均每天一起执行69次面部识别搜索。列出的顶级供应商之一是 Clearview AI ，这是一家由风投资深人士 Peter Thiel 支持的公司。

硅窥探者

由于生成式人工智能能够处理图像和视频片段等“非结构化”数据，为聊天GPT提供支持的类型的生成式人工智能可能很快会进一步增强监控能力。卫星公司 Planet Labs 的老板威尔·马歇尔 (Will Marshall) 表示，利用该技术分析卫星图像将让用户“在地球上搜索物体”，就像谷歌让用户在互联网上搜索信息一样。

对于新来者来说，向政府出售巧妙的新监控技术并不容易。 Axon 的老板 Rick Smith 指出，美国有 18,000 个警察部门。其中五分之一不使用电子记录。直到 2009 年，纽约警察局仍在购买打字机。

对于真正站稳脚跟的新人来说，回报可能是丰厚的。安德森·霍洛维茨公司美国活力基金的负责人大卫·乌列维奇（David Ulevitch）观察到，口碑可以快速传播，创造“病毒式传播”。 Fusus 是一家销售实时犯罪监控软件的初创公司，该公司表示，尽管基数较低，但去年其销售额增长了 300% 以上。 2017 年，另一家初创公司 Flock Safety 推出了车牌阅读器，目前已在美国 47 个州使用。此外，另一家风险投资公司 General Catalyst 的 Paul Kwan 指出，与政府买家的关系一旦建立，往往会持续很长时间。

较大的公司正在适应。自 2019 年以来，摩托罗拉解决方案已进行 15 项收购，其中包括视频分析工具 Calipsa 和为警车仪表板制造摄像头的 WatchGuard。 Axon 还收购了初创公司并入股了其他公司，包括 Fusus 和 Skydio。

将新技术魔法应用于监视公民的工作会让许多人感到不舒服。 2020 年，出于对隐私的担忧，亚马逊、微软和IBM停止向执法机构提供面部识别服务。但监控可能仍然有利可图，尤其是因为政府并不是这些技术的唯一客户。 Skydio 的无人机评估手机信号塔和桥梁的损坏情况。对冲基金利用卫星图像来统计零售商停车场的汽车数量，希望在市场披露之前衡量其收入。 SmartEye 是一家瑞典公司，销售眼球追踪技术来监控飞行员的情绪。它还将产品出售给广告公司。无论是老大哥还是大企业加强监控的趋势看起来都不太可能逆转。 ■

; Sun, 05 Nov 2023 17:18:41 GMT /内容/j318at28le5jp1dlr0fmj93pr8k78dva https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/05/silicon-valley-is-piling-into-the-business-of-snooping OMV, Austria’s energy major, reimagines its future

2021 年 9 月，阿尔弗雷德·斯特恩 (Alfred Stern) 就任OMV首席执行官时，用了一个词来形容奥地利的石油和天然气巨头：塑料。他之前负责管理该公司的化学品部门 Borealis，他认为OMV的未来是该业务，而不是化石燃料。全球对碳排放产品的需求迟早会达到峰值。预计到 2030 年，用于包装的原生塑料的年均增长率将达到 4.7%，快于世界GDP 的增长率；对于再生塑料来说，每年的增幅将高达 12%。

2022 年 2 月， OMV从俄罗斯购买大部分天然气，斯特恩先生在他的下属看来一定是有先见之明的，当时俄罗斯入侵了乌克兰。一个月后，他公开公布了他的新战略。从现在起，该公司将专注于生产和销售可持续燃料、化学品和材料——重点是“可持续”。它将逐渐减少石油和天然气的生产。 OMV的老板希望到本十年末，石油和天然气部门占集团营业利润的 30%，而 2019 年至 2021 年间的平均比例为 44%。化学品将占一半，高于29%。

即使在最好的情况下，这样的转变也是雄心勃勃的。 With global markets for energy, chemicals and materials all being buffeted by geopolitical and economic forces, it seems almost brazen—especially when other oil-and-gas companies are revising their green plans and doubling down on crude.

On October 31st OMV said that sales slumped by nearly half in the third quarter, compared with a year earlier, to €9.5bn ($10bn). Net profit plummeted by almost two-thirds, to €431m. Both the energy business (the exploration and production of oil and gas) and the fuel and feedstock unit (which supplies the chemicals industry) did worse than forecast. Borealis beat expectations, but still reported a loss of €11m.

Investors nevertheless seem happy with the thrust of Mr Stern's plan. Some of the earnings slide was merely a return to earth from a period of sky-high prices for oil and gas that had boosted profits a year ago. Many applauded his announcement in the earnings call of a joint venture with Interzero, a German firm, to build Europe's largest sorting plant for chemical recycling in southern Germany. Oleg Galbur of Raiffeisen International, an Austrian bank, thinks that the chemicals unit in particular has plenty of room for improvement once the cyclical industry recovers from the current economic slowdown in large markets such as China and parts of Europe.

The division's prospects could brighten further if talks between OMV and Abu Dhabi National Oil Company ( ADNOC ) aimed at uniting Borealis and Borouge, the Emirati giant's chemicals unit, succeed. That would create one of the world's biggest makers of polyolefin plastics, which would be listed and owned in equal parts by OMV and Adnoc . (Borealis already owns 36% of Borouge and ADNOC 25% of Borealis.)

Mr Stern's biggest challenge will continue to be dealing with the fallout of his company's close business ties with Russia. In 2018 his predecessor, Rainer Seele, signed a deal with Gazprom for gas deliveries until 2040. Mr Stern has made clear he is not planning to renege on that contract. But he had to write off €2.5bn in Russian assets, including a €1bn investment in Nord Stream 2, the defunct gas pipeline from Russia to Germany.

During the latest earnings call Mr Stern was at pains to reassure investors that OMV could honour its gas-delivery contracts even if Ukraine's government lived up to its intention of stopping the transit of Russian gas through pipelines on its territory by the end of 2024. He has made a big effort to find alternative gas suppliers, such as Norway. OMV has also signed a deal with BP , a British energy giant, to get liquefied natural gas via a terminal in Rotterdam. In July Mr Stern signed off on Neptun Deep, a joint project with Romgaz, a Romanian gas firm, to explore for gas in the Black Sea. Plastic may be the future. But OMV ’s present will involve energy for a while yet. ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /content/q3c0i2vfb7tciohalcc870hlv35u0kkd https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/02/omv-austrias-energy-major-reimagines-its-future Can Israeli-Emirati business ties survive the Gaza war?

I N 2020 MIDDLE EASTERN commerce was transformed. The United Arab Emirates ( UAE ) and a few other countries signed the Abraham Accords with Israel, normalising relations between the Jewish state and some of its Arab neighbours. Israeli tourists flooded into Dubai on the first ever direct flights. In the first eight months of 2023 Dubai welcomed almost 230,000 travellers from Israel, 73% more than in the same period last year. Nowadays travel agencies in Tel Aviv even offer bar-mitzvah tours in the emirate, with pit stops at kosher restaurants.

Business dealings have blossomed, too. The UAE -Israel Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement came into force in April. Official trade between the two countries is expected to surpass $3bn this year, from nothing in 2019. Last year Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, Mubadala, reportedly invested $100m in six venture-capital ( VC ) funds based in Israel or focused on Israeli startups. It also bought a $1bn stake in an offshore natural-gas field from NewMed Energy of Israel. Israeli technology companies such as Liquidity Group, a fintech darling, have opened research-and-development centres in the UAE . Israeli and Emirati universities have forged research partnerships on things like artificial intelligence.

All of this progress is now at risk as a result of the war raging between Israel and Hamas. Since the conflict erupted, reports one Israeli entrepreneur, many Emirati contacts have gone silent. An Israeli-American investor who splits his time between Dubai and Tel Aviv worries that even after the conflict abates, Arab firms will think twice about transacting with Israeli ones.

That would be unwelcome for Israel and the UAE alike. Israeli business confidence was slumping even before the hostilities in Gaza. Proposed reforms to weaken the supreme court worried corporate bosses. Amid a worldwide VC winter, Israeli startups raised less than $4bn in the first half of 2023, the lowest since the same period in 2018. More than two-fifths of Israeli companies surveyed in late October reported that their prospective backers had cancelled or delayed investment agreements. Israel's businesses could therefore use the UAE ’s deep pools of capital and access to its domestic market, especially as their country recovers from hostilities that are, according to surveys, already affecting four in five of its tech firms.

The UAE , for its part, covets Israeli know-how, which could accelerate the country's economic diversification away from oil and help it keep up with competition from its bigger neighbour, Saudi Arabia, itself in the throes of a modernisation drive (and, until the Gaza war, on course to forge diplomatic ties with Israel). In the past decade private investment in the UAE has declined as a share of GDP . Although the government has put in place various incentives for entrepreneurs, from accelerator programmes to credit guarantees, the IMF has recently pointed to the “weak technology content” of the Emirati economy. Most new tech ventures end up looking like copycats of stale e-commerce businesses. Israel, with its keen technological acumen in areas from digital technology to water desalination and a culture of free enterprise, has a lot to teach the Emiratis.

The commercial logic of continued rapprochement, then, remains sound. Many businesspeople in Israel and the UAE know it—and are hoping that the current pause is just that, rather than a collapse. ■

D uring the past year Shein and Temu, two ultra-fast-fashion upstarts famous both for $5 frocks and for playing down their Chinese heritage, have waged an internecine legal battle in America. Singapore-based Shein, the better-known of the two, threw down the frilly gauntlet, accusing Temu, which has invaded its territory in America, of stealing its trademarks and using social-media influencers to disparage it. Temu, which is based in Boston but owned by PDD , a Chinese e-commerce giant, struck back. It accused Shein of monopolistic practices like using its market power to force a network of 8,000-plus suppliers in China to refuse to do business with Temu. Then, on October 27th, Reuters reported that the firms had suspended hostilities.

To observers in the West these goings-on might once have seemed like an entertaining sideshow. But they illustrate that the cut-throat drama of Chinese e-commerce has now arrived in America. The fortunes of Shein and Temu are intricately bound up with those of some of America's biggest technology firms, such as Meta, with its social-media empire, Alphabet, owner of Google, and Amazon, America's e-commerce behemoth—not to mention physical retailers like Walmart and the dollar stores ubiquitous across American strip malls. No one likes to say this out loud, but for all the talk of Sino-American decoupling, China-linked e-commerce platforms are muscling into American business with the same shock-and-awe tactics that TikTok, a video app, used to besiege social media. For digital advertisers it is a mixed blessing. For discount retailers it is a curse. For everyone it may change the warp and weft of cross-border commerce.

Take advertising for starters. In its third-quarter results announced in late October, Meta revealed that advertisers from China, including e-commerce and gaming firms, had an “outsized” impact on revenue growth. Meta did not name the firms or quantify their impact, but supersleuths went to work. One was Brian Wieser, a former adman turned analyst, who five years ago first drew attention to the importance of Chinese advertisers on Facebook after spotting differences in company data between the geographic location of those who sell ads on its platforms and those who see them. Only this year did Meta start acknowledging China's importance, vindicating his work. Using similar location data, MoffettNathanson, a research firm, estimates that Shein and Temu provided nearly a third of Meta's revenue growth in the nine months to September, or almost $3bn (a figure well short of Mr Wieser's estimates). Alphabet, too, is reaping the bonanza. Tinuiti, a marketing firm, says that in the third quarter Temu was as big a competitor in auctions for ads on Google Shopping as Walmart. A year ago the fledgling firm was nowhere.

Then there is e-commerce. Amazon's platform has long hosted sellers of cheap goods from China. They seldom advertise their provenance. Nonetheless, Juozas Kaziukenas, founder of Marketplace Pulse, an e-commerce research firm, has combed through physical addresses to estimate that many merchants selling on Amazon are based in China. As Shein and Temu surge in popularity, some of those vendors may switch to their platforms. For now, Mr Kaziukenas does not expect the cut-price duo to materially challenge Amazon's business, which is much bigger, has a broader range of goods for sale and vastly outpaces them on speed of delivery. That said, if e-commerce in China is any guide, the upstarts will not rest until they have taken market share from American competitors, undaunted by their rivals' heft. TikTok, too, is becoming a force to be reckoned with in online shopping, using live jamborees to attract shoppers, a common practice in China. MoffettNathanson calls the triple-barrelled onslaught the “biggest disruptive threat” to e-commerce in years.

If the Asian trio loom so large, why are America's tech giants so hush-hush about them? For those enjoying the ad windfall, one reason may be questions about the longevity of Shein's and Temu's marketing sprees. In mass-market retail, with wafer-thin margins, pouring billions of dollars into digital ads is a road to ruin if it goes on too long. Meta and Alphabet may not want to draw attention to the potential volatility of the revenue streams.

Political headwinds in America may be mounting, too. Sinosceptics in Congress, in a similar tizzy about Shein and Temu as they are about TikTok, accuse the fast-fashion duo of exploiting an exception in American law that allows packages under $800 in value to enter the country duty-free and with scant inspection. It reckons the two firms are responsible for 30% of packages entering America under this rule. Closing the loophole could significantly cut the discounts the two platforms offer in America. Moreover, their algorithms draw on oceans of data about shoppers. That opens them up to the same attacks as TikTok.

One risk that the retail firms are apparently spared is a crackdown in China. With headquarters outside the country, they are less likely to suffer the fates of successful Chinese tech firms that have fallen foul of President Xi Jinping in recent years. Sky Canaves of Insider Intelligence, a data-gatherer, says their success may in fact be helping their Chinese suppliers offset the economic slowdown at home. She thinks that will boost their standing with the government.

The cat is out of the bag

It is not clear why Shein and Temu settled their legal grievances, but it will surely be a relief to the powers that be in Beijing. After all, a common front is better for the country's image abroad than a catfight on the digital catwalk. Whether the truce means they will spend less to out-market each other remains to be seen. But American tech giants are in a new world order. They are still largely shut out of China. China, by proxy, is all over their home turf. The new competition no doubt frustrates big tech. To its customers, it is a neatly wrapped gift. ■

A RMING UNCLE SAM is a great business. America's latest defence budget earmarks $170bn for procurement and $145bn for research and development ( R & D ), most of which ends up with the handful of “prime” contractors, which deal directly with the Department of Defence ( D o D ). So will some of the $44bn in American military aid to Ukraine and a chunk of the extra defence spending by America's European allies, which account for 5-10% of the primes' sales. Although those sums do not increase at the same rate as, say, corporate IT expenditure, leaving less room for spectacular gains, arms manufacturers are also shielded from eye-watering losses by huge, decades-long contracts.

Thanks to a big shake-up at the end of the cold war, the industry is also highly concentrated. At a meeting in 1993, dubbed the “last supper”, William Perry, then President Bill Clinton's deputy defence secretary, told industry bosses that excess capacity was no longer appropriate and that consolidation was in order. As a result, the ranks of the primes have thinned from more than 50 in 1950s America to six. The number of suppliers of satellites has declined from eight to four, of fixed-wing aircraft from eight to three and of tactical missiles from 13 to three.

Guaranteed custom and weak competition have helped American armsmakers' shares comfortably outperform the broader stockmarket over the past 50 years. A paper published by the D o D in April found that between 2000 and 2019 defence contractors did better than civilian ones in terms of shareholder returns, return on assets and return on equity, among other financial measures. An increasingly unstable world means more money going to the armed forces—and to their suppliers. Total shareholder returns, including dividends, at primes such as General Dynamics, Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman rose when Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022 and when Hamas attacked Israel on October 7th (see chart 1).

This cosy oligopoly is now being challenged on two fronts. One is technological. As the tank battles on Ukrainian plains and in Gazan streets show, “metal on the ground” remains important. So do missiles, artillery shells and fighter jets. But both conflicts also illustrate that modern combat relies increasingly on smaller and simpler tactical kit, as well as communications, sensors, software and data. The second challenge is the Pentagon's efforts to extract greater value for money from the military-industrial complex.

Both developments undercut the primes' big competitive advantages: their ability to build bulky kit and to navigate the mind-boggling procurement process. Cost-effective innovations, such as the Pentagon's recently announced project “Replicator”, which aims to get swarms of small drones in the air, ASAP , require agile engineering for which the defence giants “are not innately organised”, as Kearney, a consultancy, delicately puts it. If they are to thrive in the new era, they will have to rediscover some of the innovative ways that helped them shape Silicon Valley in the decades after the second world war. So far, though, they are finding this difficult.

It is easy to see why the primes (and their investors) like the current setup. The D o D reimburses the primes' R & D expenses, and adds 10-15% on top of that. This “cost plus” approach spares the companies from funnelling lots of their own capital into risky projects, which offers security but reduces the incentive to deliver things on time and on budget. The project to build the F -35 fighter jet, which has accounted for more than a quarter of Lockheed's revenues in the past three years, started life in the 1990s. It is running around a decade late and will cost American taxpayers up to $2trn over the lifetime of the aircraft.

Once in production, newly developed large kit is sold at a fixed price, often for decades. The B -21 stealth bomber currently in development by Northrop Grumman will cost the Pentagon more than $200bn for 100 planes delivered over 30 years. The Columbia Class nuclear-submarine programme made by a subsidiary of General Dynamics will sail from the early 2030s until at least 2085.

Past their prime

The Pentagon's patience with this time-honoured business model is wearing thin. Last year's national-defence strategy summed it up succinctly: “too slow and too focused on acquiring systems not designed to address the most critical challenges we now face”. Instead, it wants to “reward rapid experimentation, acquisition and fielding”. This is forcing the primes to think about how they could build fresh functionality atop their existing platforms, by adding new software, modules, payloads and the like, and to create production processes which can be modified to accommodate innovations.

As Lockheed Martin's chief executive, Jim Taiclet, recently acknowledged, soldiers expect seamless integration of sensors, weapons and systems for battle management such as joint all-domain command and control ( JADC 2), a new concept for sharing data between platforms, services and theatres. Contracting, building and continuously updating such systems will be a struggle for firms that have hitherto produced huge bits of hardware slowly and which, in the words of Steve Grundman of the Atlantic Council, a think-tank, are not “digital natives”.

The primes face another problem. The technology the Pentagon has in mind is not inherently military, observes Mikhail Grinberg of Renaissance Strategic Advisors, a consultancy. Most of the defence giants do have civilian divisions—large ones in the case of Boeing, General Dynamics and Raytheon. But the Pentagon's growing appetite for dual-use technologies means more competition from civilian industry, which is constantly devising new equipment, materials, manufacturing processes and software that could be used for military as well as peaceful ends.

In 2020 General Motors won a contract to supply infantry vehicles. The carmaker has now teamed up with the American arm of Rheinmetall, a German weapons firm, in a deal to furnish military trucks. Other challengers are trying to muscle their way into the military-industrial complex, drawn by the D o D ’s appetite for more diverse systems. Palantir, founded in 2003 to help avert more attacks like that of September 11th 2001, makes civilian and military software that processes the vast amounts of data that modern life and warfare throw up. Elon Musk's Space X sends payloads, including military ones, into orbit and is being paid by the D o D to provide internet access to Ukrainian forces in their fight against Russian invaders.

Big tech is getting in on the action, too. Amazon, Google and Microsoft have targeted defence and security as promising markets, says Mr Grundman. Military procurement is a rare business large enough to make a difference to the tech titans' top lines, which are counted in the hundreds of billions of dollars. The trio, along with Oracle, a smaller maker of business software, are already sharing a $9bn cloud-computing contract with the Pentagon. Microsoft also supplies the army with augmented-reality goggles in a deal that could eventually be worth $22bn.

The Pentagon's new approach is also attracting upstart rivals. Anduril, a firm founded in 2017 solely to serve military needs, has developed Lattice, a general-purpose software platform that can be swiftly updated and adapted to solve new problems. The company also makes a short-range drone called the Ghost, which can be operated by a couple of soldiers. Recognising that to win business quickly it needs to be vertically integrated, it has acquired a manufacturer of rocket engines and is developing an underwater autonomous vessel for the Australian navy.

The wannabe primes and their financial backers still bemoan the barriers to new entrants. Brian Schimpf, Anduril's boss, says that when working with the D o D you get “punched in the face every day”. SpaceX and Palantir both had to fight court battles just to be able to contest military contracts. In June Palantir signed an open letter with 11 other companies, including Anduril, and investors, imploring the Pentagon to remove obstacles to smaller contractors. The letter, which drew on proposals from the Atlantic Council, condemned “antiquated methods” that “drastically limited” access to commercial innovation.

As the national-security strategy shows, the D o D seems keen to move away from procurement antiquity, for example by shifting more risk onto contractors through fixed-price, rather than cost-plus, development contracts. Such developments are causing palpitations among the primes. Boeing's recent financial travails are partly a result of catastrophically underbidding in fixed-price contracts for the KC -46 tanker and Air Force One, which ferries around American presidents.

In contrast, Anduril has dispensed with the crutch of cost-plus of its own accord, and is investing its own capital to make what it thinks the D o D will need. By clinging on to the old model, the primes may be depriving America of the 21st-century defence industry it needs. ■

; Wed, 01 Nov 2023 18:59:12 GMT /content/qighd6r7dnnntc0dckojandi723r10p9 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/01/can-americas-weapons-makers-adapt-to-21st-century-warfare How to get the lying out of hiring

H iring processes can be thought of as a battle between candour and dishonesty. You might imagine this is a simple fight between truth-seeking firms and self-promoting candidates, and to a certain extent it is. But companies themselves are prone to bend reality out of shape in ways that are self-defeating.

Start with the obvious culprits: job applicants. The point of a CV or a LinkedIn profile is to massage reality into the most appealing shape possible. Everyone beyond a certain level of experience is a transformational leader personally responsible for generating millions in revenue; the world economy would be about 15 times bigger than it actually is if all such claims were true. The average Briton spends four and a half hours a day watching TV and online videos. But the average job candidate uses their spare time only for worthy purposes, like volunteering in soup kitchens or teaching orphans to code.

The cover letter is so open in its insincerity (“When I saw the advertisement for this job, I almost fainted with excitement”) that people are starting not to bother with it. At the interview stage one task facing the firm's recruiters is to winkle out the truth of what a person actually contributed to a project. Those hoary questions about a candidate's weaknesses and failures are there for a reason; no one will bring them up unprompted. Cognitive and behavioural tests are useful in part because they are harder for applicants to game.

In our new seven-part podcast series, Boss Class , our Bartleby columnist searches for the secrets to being a better manager. Episode two looks at hybrid working and episode three explores how to get hiring right.

But a tendency to stretch the truth infects companies as well as applicants. The typical firm will write a job description that invariably describes the work environment as fast-paced and innovative, and then lays out a set of improbable requirements for the “ideal candidate”, someone who almost by definition does not exist. Sometimes—as when ads demand more years of experience in a programming language than that language has existed for—these requirements include an ability to go back and alter the course of history.

Industrialised hiring processes can often reward mindless exaggeration. Services that scan your résumé when you are making an application mark you down if your CV does not match the keywords that appear in the original job advertisement. The message is clear: to get through to the next stage, you have to contort yourself to meet corporate expectations.

Substance can matter less to recruiters than form. One software engineer says she got a 90%-plus response rate with a spoof CV showing apparent spells at Microsoft and Instagram but also boasting, among other things, that she had increased team-bonding by organising the company potato-sack race and “spread Herpes STD to 60% of intern team”. References are so prone to inaccuracy that many firms have a policy of not giving them, fearing legal action from defamed candidates or deceived employers.

Too few firms offer an accurate account of what a position actually involves. Tracey Franklin, the chief HR officer for Moderna, a fast-growing drugmaker—and an interviewee in this week's episode of Boss Class , our new podcast—is a fan of “realistic job previews” ( RJP s). These are meant to give prospective recruits a genuine sense of the negatives and positives of the job, as well as a clear idea of the company's corporate culture. One effective tactic is to lay out, in text or video, what a typical day in the role would look like.

Such honesty can be its own reward. Research has long suggested that RJP s lead to lower turnover and higher employee satisfaction. A paper in 2011 by David Earnest of Towson University and his co-authors concluded that favourable perceptions of the organisation's honesty are the best explanation for why.

The incentives on both sides of the hiring process lean naturally towards glossing reality. If candidates were to give genuinely truthful answers (“I have a habit of making basic but calamitous errors”), many would rule themselves out of jobs. And if firms were to give a warts-and-all description of themselves, many would end up deterring good applicants. But a process designed to uncover the truth about job applicants would run a lot more smoothly if firms were also honest about themselves. ■
